description.narrative: To strengthen the management effectiveness of the Protected Area system of Swaziland to ensure a viable set of representative samples of the country’s full range of natural ecosystems are conserved, through a network of PAs.

Legally protected PA network increased. Number of capacity building programmes developed for improved PA management Number of biodiversity field surveys Number of information management systems at regional and national level Number of landscape-based management plans Number of informal PAs established as National PAs Number of new PAs gazetted and operationalised Number of streamlined PA and landscape management structures and standards developed Number of training programmes developed Number of invasive alien species control programmes Number of conservation infrastructure or equipment programmes Number of ecotourism infrastructure, product development or marketing programmes Number of CBNRM programs developed

comment.narrative: 1. Protected Area Coverage - 3.9% 2. Limited national capacities for systemitised knowledge base and PA management. 3. Low invetsment through landscape approach.

1. National biodiversity status established: GIS Biodiversity Platform operationalized; Three nationals trained in management of the biodiversity portal; Number of species specific research reports produced. 2. Increased protected area national coverage: Percent of PA endorsed; Number of gazettes drafted. 3. Capacity Development Programme and Training Manuals produced for improved management of protected areas. 4. Improved ecosystem management in the fours (4) cluster areas Ngwempisi, Mkhaya West, Malolotja and Lubombo: Number of Chiefdom Development Plans (CDP) with integration of conservation management; Number of community members participating in biodiversity monitoring; Number of protected wetlands; Number of hectares with removed invasive plant species; one (1) range land management; Number of reintroduced species (and rehabilitated space area); Number of nurseries supported. 5. Sustainable financing of protected areas improved: SF Assessment Report; Number of PAs Management Plans; Number of PAs Business Plans; Number of Business Score Cards. 6. Protected Areas infrastructure improved: Length of fence constructed for selected PA areas; Number of chalets constructed. 7. Partnerships for strengthened national protected areas and community conservation management interventions: Three (3) Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) signed with SNTC for support to landscape programming for effective PAs. 8. Strengthen National Protected Areas Systems in Swaziland Project Mid-term Review Report.

1. GIS Biodiversity Platform operationalized and national staff trained in its management; Three nationals trained in management of the biodiversity portal; Nine (9) Biodiversity surveys conducted in the following areas: Lubombo Cluster (Shewula, Mambane and Jilobi), Ngwempisi Cluster (Sigcineni, Ntfungula, and Velezizweni), and Malolotja Cluster (Ekuvinjelweni, Mvembili, and Bulembu). The reports provide a description of floristic assemblages, small mammals, reptiles, amphibians and a selected group of insects at the nine sites. 2. Five PAs have been gazetted resulting in increase in coverage from 3.9% to 4.1%.
3. Five (5) Protected Area entities assisted with business development. The Capacity Development Programme are under developed. Training Manuals have not been produced for improved management of protected areas. 4. Improved ecosystem management in the fours (4) cluster areas Ngwempisi, Mkhaya West, Malolotja and Lubombo: Three (3) Chiefdom Development Plans (CDP) with integration of conservation management completed; Number of community members participating in biodiversity monitoring; ten (10) Wetland systems protected covering 87.6 ha (17km worth of fencing was used); 600ha of invasive plant species cleared; one (1) One range land management area designated at Ntondozi; No species were re/introduced; One nursery supported at Ntondozi Community Botanical Gardens.
5. Sustainable financing of protected areas improved: SF Assessment Report produced; No PAs Management Plans, Business Plans and Business Score Cards were developed. 6. Protected Areas infrastructure improved: 46.7km of fencing provided to support four PAs (Mantini Nature Reserve, Lubetse Nature Reserve, Phophonyane Conservancy, Mlawula, and Shewula Mountain Camp); 5 PAs have been awarded with two (2) million worth of catalytic funding to assist in PA strengthening; Malolotja Nature Reserve assisted with rehabilitation of 10km roads within the Park; Rehabilitation of Khelekhele Camp Site underway; Construction of Lodge in Ntfungula Mountain with 8 Chalets, 1 Common Room and one office underway; Swaziland Game Ranchers Association (SGRA) trained on law enforcement. 7. Partnerships for strengthened national protected areas and community conservation management interventions: Six (6) Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) signed with SNTC: Swaziland Environmental Authority (SEA), Swaziland Tourism Authority, Swaziland Water and Agricultural Development Enterprise; Surveyor General, University of Swaziland Lubombo Conservancy/ COSPE. Other non-formalized partnerships include National Agricultural Maize Board (NAMBOARD), Small enterprises Development Company 8. The Strengthen National Protected Areas Systems in Swaziland Project Mid-term Review was not undertaken, however prioritised for 2018

1. National biodiversity status established: GIS Biodiversity Platform operationalized; data sourcing and uploading into portal 2. Capacity Development Programme for improved management of protected areas: Capacity Development Programme and Training Manuals produced for improved management of protected areas; Number of SNTC staff trained on Species identification, ecological monitoring and field guiding; Number of SNTC staff trained on Management and Planning; Number of SNTC staff trained on customer service, eco-tourism management, marketing and branding, advertising and financial management; Number of SNTC law enforcement staff trained on Swazi Conservation laws, law enforcement, anti-poaching, crime scene investigation; SNTC institutional Strengthening (SNTC Strategic plan, SNTC resource Mobilisation strategy, SNTC institutional capacity review) . 3. Improved ecosystem management in the fours (4) cluster areas Ngwempisi, Mkhaya West, Malolotja and Lubombo: Number of Conservation guidelines developed; Number of community Trusts or Natural Resource Management Committees established and capacitated; Number of protected wetlands; Number of hectares with removed invasive plant species; Number of reintroduced species (and rehabilitated space area); ecosystem valuation for SNTC Parks; number of new conservation areas established and/or strengthened; research on biodiversity management issues. 4. Sustainable financing of protected areas improved: Number of PAs Management Plans; Number of PAs Business Plans; Number of Business Score Cards; Number of community members benefiting from livelihood interventions 5. Protected Areas infrastructure improved: Length of fence constructed for selected PA areas; Number of chalets constructed; number of conservation infrastructure purchased/installed. 6. Partnerships for strengthened national protected areas and community conservation management interventions: Number of Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) or land-owner agreements signed with SNTC for support to landscape programming for effective PAs. 7. Species re-introduction: Numbers of species re-introduced or re-allocated 8. Improved Legal and Policy Framework: Development of wetland Management policy; Development of Ecotourism policy 9. Improved awareness and documentation of biodiversity conservation: Number of information products; social media coverage of biodiversity issues; national media coverage of biodiversity issues 10. Strengthen National Protected Areas Systems in Swaziland Project Mid-term Review Report.

1. GIS biodiversity platform is being operationalized through the employment of a GIS Coordinator. 2. 16 SNTC staff have been trained on Management and Planning. 9 of these were male, while 7 were female. Training on law enforcement, conservation laws, anti poaching and crime scene investigation for 19
• A weapon Handling training was undertaken by the Royal Swaziland Police and was attended by 20 Rangers, 18 of whom were males below the age of 30 while 2 were females above the age of 35. • An IAPS Control and Management workshop was facilitated for Private Land Owners.
• Development of a Strategic Plan for ENTC was enabled. The Resource mobilization strategy is still under development.
3) 22 wetlands covering approximately 180ha of land have been fenced of and protected across the four clusters. This was aimed at improving and restoring he wetland ecosystem. Four (4) of the wetlands (Mvembili, Khalangilile, Mphini and Lukhetseni) have recovered to the point where communities are now harvesting (under close guidance) wetland resources for improved livelihoods. The project is currently tracking the monetary value of this impact.
An IAPS Capacity building pilot program was facilitated initiated in Luzelweni aimed at building the capacity for communities to control and manage IAPS (black wattle/ acacia mearnsii. IAPS removal was also undertaken in 5 Protected Areas covering approximately 300 ha of land. 4) The process of developing management plans for the three (3) SNTC PAs (Malolotja, Mlawula and Mantenga) was undertaken this year, and a draft is in place. 3 Business plans development for 3 eco lodges were facilitated. A total of 970 households benefited from the Fruit Tree livelihood program to date. 300 of these benefited in 2018. 11 (schools and chiefdoms) institutions benefited as well. 5. The project has also supported efforts towards improving conservation infrastructure. This includes 15 km of fencing for Mlawula and 4.6 km of fencing in Mhlosinga Nature Reserve. Conservation infrastructure was also purchased for SNTC part of which is being used for the law enforcement training. 6. No MoUs of land-owner agreements have been signed in 2018. However as part of the in line with the recommendations of the MTR the focus in 2019 will be strengthening the Protected areas through supporting the effective management of conservation areas and Land Owner Agreements will be prioritized. 7. 6 giraffes were re-introduced into Dombeya Game reserve in 2018.
8. The development of the wetland Management policy in on-going. A concept note has been developed and TOR drafted. 9. The project has an ongoing social media page and a newly initiated newsletter to raise awareness on the projects interventions and on biodiversity conservation.
10. The mid-term review of the SNPAS project was conducted.

Improved ecosystem management in the fours (4) cluster areas Ngwempisi, Mkhaya West, Malolotja and Lubombo: Number of Conservation guidelines developed; Number of community Trusts or Natural Resource Management Committees established and capacitated; Number of protected wetlands; Number of hectares with removed invasive plant species; Number of reintroduced species (and rehabilitated space area); ecosystem valuation for SNTC Parks; number of new conservation areas established and/or strengthened; research on biodiversity management issues. 4. Sustainable financing of protected areas improved: Number of PAs Management Plans; Number of PAs Business Plans; Number of Business Score Cards; Number of community members benefiting from livelihood interventions 5. Protected Areas infrastructure improved: Length of fence constructed for selected PA areas; Number of chalets constructed; number of conservation infrastructure purchased/installed. 6. Partnerships for strengthened national protected areas and community conservation management interventions: Number of Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) or land-owner agreements signed with SNTC for support to landscape programming for effective PAs. 7. Species re-introduction: Numbers of species re-introduced or re-allocated 8. Improved Legal and Policy Framework: Development of wetland Management policy; Development of Ecotourism policy 9. Improved awareness and documentation of biodiversity conservation: Number of information products; social media coverage of biodiversity issues; national media coverage of biodiversity issues 10. Strengthen National Protected Areas Systems in Swaziland Project Mid-term Review Report.

1. GIS biodiversity platform is being operationalized through the employment of a GIS Coordinator. 2. 16 SNTC staff have been trained on Management and Planning. 9 of these were male, while 7 were female. Training on law enforcement, conservation laws, anti poaching and crime scene investigation for 19
• A weapon Handling training was undertaken by the Royal Swaziland Police and was attended by 20 Rangers, 18 of whom were males below the age of 30 while 2 were females above the age of 35. • An IAPS Control and Management workshop was facilitated for Private Land Owners.
• Development of a Strategic Plan for ENTC was enabled. The Resource mobilization strategy is still under development.
3) 22 wetlands covering approximately 180ha of land have been fenced of and protected across the four clusters. This was aimed at improving and restoring he wetland ecosystem. Four (4) of the wetlands (Mvembili, Khalangilile, Mphini and Lukhetseni) have recovered to the point where communities are now harvesting (under close guidance) wetland resources for improved livelihoods. The project is currently tracking the monetary value of this impact.
An IAPS Capacity building pilot program was facilitated initiated in Luzelweni aimed at building the capacity for communities to control and manage IAPS (black wattle/ acacia mearnsii. IAPS removal was also undertaken in 5 Protected Areas covering approximately 300 ha of land. 4) The process of developing management plans for the three (3) SNTC PAs (Malolotja, Mlawula and Mantenga) was undertaken this year, and a draft is in place. 3 Business plans development for 3 eco lodges were facilitated. A total of 970 households benefited from the Fruit Tree livelihood program to date. 300 of these benefited in 2018. 11 (schools and chiefdoms) institutions benefited as well. 5. The project has also supported efforts towards improving conservation infrastructure. This includes 15 km of fencing for Mlawula and 4.6 km of fencing in Mhlosinga Nature Reserve. Conservation infrastructure was also purchased for SNTC part of which is being used for the law enforcement training. 6. No MoUs of land-owner agreements have been signed in 2018. However as part of the in line with the recommendations of the MTR the focus in 2019 will be strengthening the Protected areas through supporting the effective management of conservation areas and Land Owner Agreements will be prioritized. 7. 6 giraffes were re-introduced into Dombeya Game reserve in 2018.
8. The development of the wetland Management policy in on-going. A concept note has been developed and TOR drafted. 9. The project has an ongoing social media page and a newly initiated newsletter to raise awareness on the projects interventions and on biodiversity conservation.
10. The mid-term review of the SNPAS project was conducted.

1. Biodiversity data and information generation and management enhanced in the country through assessment reports: Integrated Biodiversity: Sustainable Financing: Socio-Economic Profile and Protected Areas Feasibility; Assessment Report; Vegetation and Land-use cover Maps. 2. GIS knowledge-based system in place. 3. Six (6) Gazettes drafted for expansion of protected areas in the country. 4. Increased engagement and involvement of rural communities and private sector in biodiversity management through protected areas: Four (4) partnership established; 75% of the 26 Chiefdoms trained in Chiefdom Development Plans and developing the CPDs with an integration of conservation management.

1. Increase access to biodiversity information and data was facilitated through the establishment of the Biodiversity Portal for the country: www.swazibiodiversity.com . The portal has knowledge products such as land-use maps for the 31 Chiefdoms working with the project. The vegetation cover maps for the country was also produced showing change in land-use activities over a period of 15 years (2005, 2010 and 2015). The socioeconomic, integrated biodiversity and sustainable financing are underway.
2. The Biodiversity GIS knowledge-based system was established and facilitates access to already collected data and information together with the training manual.
3. Guidelines gazetting and de-gazetting are in place. Draft gazetting instruments have been produced to facilitate increased coverage of protected areas in the country form the 3.9% in 2014 to 6.4% in 2020.
4. Four (4) partnership established: 100% of all the 31 Chiefdoms oriented on the Chiefdom Development Plans. Partnerships have been established with the Swaziland Water and Agriculture Enterprise (SWADE) and the Ministry of Tinkhundla Administration and Development (MTAD) for the training of the traditional leaders and Inner Councils as well as the Chiefdom Development Committees. Participatory biodiversity research working with community members from the 4 (four) created employment for 58 (IRRF 1.3.2).
MOU was entered into with the General Surveyor’s Office for the ownership and administration of use of the produced Vegetation Maps in the country. Additionally, an MOU was also facilitated with three entities, Eco-Lubombo, COSPE and Lubombo Conservancy to collaborate on building the Lubombo cluster capacities for effective protected areas management (IRRF 1.3.1).

MOU was entered into with the General Surveyor’s Office for the ownership and administration of use of the produced Vegetation Maps in the country. Additionally, an MOU was also facilitated with three entities, Eco-Lubombo, COSPE and Lubombo Conservancy to collaborate on building the Lubombo cluster capacities for effective protected areas management (IRRF 1.3.1).
